Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: An Integrated Approach to Convex Optimization Algorithms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Image reconstruction and feature extraction have been important aspects in various applications such as medical resonance imaging (MRI) and synthetic aperture radar (SAR). However, these procedures involve challenges. Different applications may vary in data acquisition (sampling) domains, levels of detail required, and processing domains for the features of interest. The data acquisition is usually under-prescribed and noisy. The sampling domains and/or processing domains may not be well suited for the underlying question. All of these make the problems ill-posed, and various regularization techniques are necessary to study the problems by formulating them as convex optimization models. This project will develop an integrated framework of investigating such convex optimization models. The project will provide graduate students with opportunities for training through research involvement and will prepare them for careers in science and engineering.

The PIs aim to propose a systematic way of evaluating various regularization techniques in such models, conduct a rigorous numerical analysis of the models, and develop efficient numerical algorithms of solving the models. Specifically, the PIs will address the following technical questions: (1) What constraints must be placed on the collected data in order to construct a numerically robust approximation to the underlying function? (2) How quickly and in what sense does the approximation converge? (3) Are the corresponding numerical algorithms developed for the fidelity and regularization terms viable? (4) How well are perturbations from the original data tolerated? The project aims to provide answers to all of these questions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this digitalized world, people rely on various kinds of data for interpretation and/or analysis. In different applications, the level of details required can vary significantly. For example, texture and variation details are critical in fingerprint recognition used in biometric security. On the flip side, clinicians and diagnosticians in medical resonance imaging (MRI) are often only interested in the shapes that outline a specific region of interest. Data acquisition also varies considerably across application domains. For instance, MRI and Synthetic-aperture radar (SAR) data are acquired as Fourier samples, while in weather and climate models, raw data are collected at irregularly spaced observation positions. Regardless of the modality, data must be processed accurately, robustly, and efficiently, so that it may be effectively used in downstream applications (e.g. diagnostics, forecast modeling). The choice of processing domain varies by application, and is generally chosen to be "optimal" based on a combination of factors including best fit to the features of interest, possible dimension reduction or compressibility, and numerical efficiency. In an idealized situation, an image or its important features can be recovered by simple inversion or transformation. However, in practice this is rarely true. The data acquisition system is usually underprescribed, noisy, and either the sampling or processing domain (or both) is not well suited for the underlying problem.

 

In this project, the PI and her collaborators and students have developed a series of algorithms to reconstruct high quality images from incomplete, noisy data; to enhance the resolution of low quality images due to the limitation of data collection machines; to effectively extract region of interest from medical images. Fourteen peer reviewed journal and conference proceeding papers are published. 

 

All of these problems are ill-posed, and various regularization techniques have been studied to solve them by formulating them as convex optimization problems. The PIs have proposed a systematic way of evaluating various regularization techniques in such models, conducted a rigorous numerical analysis of the models, and developed efficient numerical algorithms of solving the models. The project has provided several graduate and undergraduate students with opportunities for training through research involvement and have prepared them for careers in science and engineering. Four PhD dissertations and several undergraduate Capstone projects were finished in these topics.



The PIs have also worked with domain scientists from remote sensing, medical imaging for broader impacts. We have worked on enhancing resolutions of multispectral/hyperspectral images and on segmenting aorta, muscles from medical images.
